questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with schizophrenia and Tardive dyskinesia. which of the following is the most appropriate drug treatment:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Clozapine Analyze The Question: The patient has tardive dyskinesia and schizophrenia. Tardive dyskinesia is due to typical antipsychotics, and to overcome this side effect, you need to shift to an atypical antipsychotic like clozapine which doesn't produce tardive dyskinesia. Tardive dyskinesia is because of long-term d2 blockade. If they specifically ask you to manage only tardive dyskinesia, valproate will be the answer. Droperidol and chlorpromazine are typical antipsychotics, and they cause tardive dyskinesia.

questions.text: Lithium was given for BPD, and the patient developed coarse tremors after 2 weeks of therapy. The physician advised doing plasma level monitoring of lithium, and the ideal time for lithium estimation is?
questions.correct_answer: C. 12 hours after the last dose
questions.explanation:
Solution:

12 hours after the last dose

Highyeild:

Lithium has a narrow therapeutic range and it has high pharmacokinetic inter-individual variability of 0.6–1 mEq/L. So it requires TDM. By convention, the serum Li + concentration is measured from samples obtained 10–12 h after the last oral dose of the day. When the peaks are reached, intoxication may result, even when concentrations in morning samples of plasma at the daily nadir are in the acceptable range of 0.6–1 mEq/L Note: Schedule: It should be done after 10 -12 hours of intake of last dose on 5 -6 days of initiation of therapy initially. After 5-6 days because it needs to achieve a steady state followed by every 3 months if drugs levels are within the therapeutic range

Clozapine This patient has negative symptoms of Schizophrenia The Drug of choice for Negative Symptoms is Clozapine. Haloperidol is the preferred drug for acute schizophrenia. Loxapine is a Dibenzoxazepine having CPZ-like DA blocking and antipsychotic activity. There is no clear-cut advantage over other antipsychotics. Pimozide is a selective DA antagonist with little Alpha-adrenergic or cholinergic blocking activity. Because of the long duration of action (several days; elimination t½ 48-60 hours) after a single oral dose, it is considered good for maintenance therapy but not when psychomotor agitation is prominent.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aripiprazole Aripiprazole is the only antipsychotic that is FDA approved for the treatment of Tourette disorder, first line agent. Tourette’s syndrome is characterized by multiple motor or phonic tics (which may be awkward or obscene) prevalent mostly among children . It is treated symptomatically with behavioural therapy and training. It is often supplemented by typical antipsychotic drugs, especially haloperidol or pimozide. Atypical antipsychotics like risperidone and aripiprazole have also been found to help overcome compulsive tics.
